captions.text: What is Science?

[Michael Shermer]
Science is the best tool ever devised
For understanding how the world works

[Jacob Bronowski]
Science is a very human form of knowledge
We are always at the brink of the known

[Carl Sagan]
Science is a collaborative enterprise
Spanning the generations
We remember those who prepared the way
Seeing for them also

[Neil deGrasse Tyson]
If you're scientifically literate,
The world looks very different to you
And that understanding empowers you

[Richard Dawkins]
There's real poetry in the real world
Science is the poetry of reality

[Sagan]
We can do science
And with it, we can improve our lives

[Dawkins]
There's real poetry in the real world
Science is the poetry of reality

[Jill Tarter]
The story of humans is the story of ideas
That shine light into dark corners

[Lawrence Krauss]
Scientists love mysteries
They love not knowing

[Richard Feynman]
I don't feel frightened by not knowing things
I think it's much more interesting

[Brian Greene]
There's a larger universal reality
of which we are all a part

[Stephen Hawking]
The further we probe into the universe
The more remarkable are the discoveries we make

[Carolyn Porco]
The quest for the truth, in and of itself,
Is a story that's filled with insights

[Dawkins]
There's real poetry in the real world
Science is the poetry of reality

[Sagan]
We can do science
And with it, we can improve our lives

[Dawkins]
There's real poetry in the real world
Science is the poetry of reality

[Tarter]
The story of humans is the story of ideas
That shine light into dark corners

[Greene]
From our lonely point in the cosmos
We have through the power of thought
Been able to peer back to a brief moment
After the beginning of the universe

[PZ Myers]
I think that science changes the way your mind works
To think a little more deeply about things

[Dawkins]
Science replaces private prejudice
With publicly verifiable evidence

[Dawkins]
There's real poetry in the real world
Science is the poetry of reality

[Sagan]
We can do science
And with it, we can improve our lives
Thanks to Filipe Calvario (123Calvario) for the subs!

title: Symphony of Science - The Poetry of Reality (An Anthem for Science)

comments.text: what is the image in the minute 2,39?﻿
comments.author: Freddy Barrantes Perez

comments.text:
Is there a mathematical formula for spirituality... or do we just skip 
that? Like, this poetry of reality is only concerned with numbers, facts 
and figures... while the reality of a human is way broader then that. I 
know all of us are raised to calculated... thats what we do now.. But this 
is what it leads to... Worship of science... All hail Einstein. Bunch of 
Vulcans... I'm sorry, i'm all for science... but in my eyes this is 
becoming a little too much and a little scary... I'm starting to get flash 
backs to the dark ages. Then we called it God... now we call it E=MC². 
Either way, we all agree upon one thing and everybody that doesnt think 
alike is lesser... 
But about one thing we are sure... in about 100 years people will laugh at 
us and say: My God! They actually believed that THAT was reality... And 
they ALL agreed upon it. Anyways... 1+1=2. The root of 64 is 8... According 
to my calculations your feelings are inadequate.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: Tycho_

comments.text:
You don't always need to completely understand math to dabble in science. 
Alessandro Volta actually had pretty poor math skills so when studying 
electricity he had a hard time grasping the vectors of the electric field. 
Because of this he came up with electric potential that instead used 
scalars which made made the math a lot easier. From his concept of electric 
potential came voltage or a change in electric potential.
comments.author: Scott Thiel

comments.text:
+Tycho_ I've felt the same way. I care about caring about math, but I don't 
actually care about math. Math is not the only faculty of the practice of 
scientific thinking. You do not have to remember how to convert the molar 
mass in grams to particles of a sheet of tinfoil to do great things for 
your fellow human beings. 

(sorry if this looks really cheesey)
From the day we arrive on the planet
And blinking, step into the sun
There's more to see than can ever be seen
More to do than can ever be done
There's far too much to take in here
More to find than can ever be found
But the sun rolling high
Through the sapphire sky
Keeps great and small on the endless round

It's the Circle of Life
And it moves us all
Through despair and hope
Through faith and love
Till we find our place
On the path unwinding
In the Circle
The Circle of Life
comments.author: Sterling “TheOddSter” S.

balance. 5 years work, and for nothing....

comments.text:
You do raise a valid point, Hopefully people realize the difference soon, 
or there won't be much of a future to speak of for humans.
comments.author: Jacen Thomas

comments.text:
Science is the basis of almost everything warlike, the assault rifles, the 
rocket launchers, the atomic bombs dropped on Japan, they all originated 
from science. But science is also a basis for uniting nations. People who 
have loss limbs now can use robotic prosthetic limbs to become the normal 
human, those with incurable diseases now have a chance for survival thanks 
to new formulas that fight the illnesses. Science may very well be both our 
demise and our salvation.
comments.author: Vinalgin

comments.text:
And that day will be the day when we are truly united. These wars hinder 
our search for knowledge, so in order to advance as a species, we MUST stop 
these wars and use science to move forward, not to kill our fellow humans.
comments.author: Jacen Thomas

comments.text:
Hey slayer... whats up pup:) I don't think we can do without the 
sciences... well maybe philosophy or biology... just kidding, man I hated 
biology:) and give up because it MIGHT be wrong... it is almost certainly 
wrong about most theoretical things and amounts to little more than a 
philosophical explanation of of the laws of nature. and the laws of nature 
are not influenced by science in any way shape or form... but that's ok... 
it's adequate for that purpose. but you do get that a philosophy 
dictates... wait for it....THAT YOU QUESTION EVERYTHING:) glad you came 
back...peace:)
comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:
+walterdelle
I have a question.  What do we do without science.  Science has lead to how 
our modern world works.  Your computer/phone was created by people who were 
scientifically literate.  If we just give up on science because it might be 
wrong we'll be without ambition, sort of like the dark ages.
comments.author: GrimspySlayer

comments.text:
Look I'm not saying science is a bad tool... it's not, it's an incredible 
tool. but it's just a tool and it's not the only tool in the old box... and 
even if science proves something is true... the odds are against it... 
question everything:). .
comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:
Indeed Bob:) part of it is that we do have the ability to comprehend the 
unfathomable... no matter how long you ponder or how little... it comes in 
blinding flashes that dissipate as fast as they occur... but they leave you 
with that...glimmer of something... something that is right on the tip of 
your tongue...you know it but you just can't quite spit it out ya know. Man 
I love that... we are indeed strangers in a strange land:) oh that's a 
great song... going to post it:)
comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:
+BelieveNoGod Well, I believe that there is no end to figuring out all the 
mysteries of the universe because there is infinite things to be known. We 
can't possibly know everything, but we can find out as much we can and make

comments.text:
it is a tool that is used to influence the way we think.... so I guess your 
right in a way... but that still leads me back to...Break your

comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:

comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:
Science is a "tool" used to understand the universe, but more so science is

comments.author: AutoEncore TCG

comments.text:
No, I do not know that there are no supernatural things in the universe. I 
do not know if humanity is capable of understanding all the mysteries of 
the universe. I do know that science, religion, logic, philosophy, etc are 
misleading for things are not always what they seem. I do know that we are 
not educated but conditioned to obey and believe, through a system of 
punishments and rewards we are conditioned like a litter of Pavlovian 
puppies so that when they ring the bell we drool on cue. And I do think 
that it is up to each of us to break that conditioning, open our minds and 
question everything. I do think the laws of nature are concrete and true. 
That they exist independent of the mind of man, that it does not matter 
what we think of them, how we think of them or even if we think of them at 
all they remain objective truths. I do think that once we realize that 
those truths exist we are naturally compelled to seek them, and if we are 
persistent and honest they lead to the contemplation of God. I do know that 
contemplating the mysteries of God is the most satisfying endeavor I have 
ever undertaken... and I do think that you may be a bit simple minded and I 
know you are definitely closed minded. Break your conditioning, Free your 
mind and question everything;)
comments.author: walterdelle

comments.text:
+walterdelle Of course science is about detecting patterns.
That's a sure way, of confirming whatever the scientist have discovered.
And yes, most of what we know, will sooner or later be confirmed as wrong.
But at least the scientists stand up, and admit they were wrong, and the 
error is corrected.
Eventually, (if we aren't held back by religious nutheads,) the humanity 
will figure out all the 'mysteries' of the universe.
There are NO supernatural things in the universe, there's just things we 
don't understand yet.
You know that, don't you ?

comments.author: Kirk R

comments.text:
I know it must be hard to see the other side of videos like this...but bear 
with me.

This video, among other things, helped me finally speak out for the first 
time in my life. About a lifetime of religious abuse. 

Some people resort to science to sound pretentious, and it is damned 
annoying! But some people find science after a lifetime of ignorance...and 
use it to find courage. 

Some people actually need to be told that it's okay to be a materialist, to 
not be a supernaturalist...and to still find beauty in the world. It took 
me a long time to figure that out, but I did.

I know how hard it is to be patient with people...but sometimes, there's 
more going on beneath the surface than you think.

comments.text:
*Der 14. Mai ist der 134. Tag des gregorianischen Kalenders* (der 135. in 
Schaltjahren), somit verbleiben noch 231 Tage bis zum Jahresende.
Noch 23 Wochen und 3 Tage zur guten alten Zeitrechnung.

Video-Wochenmotto: Symphony Of Science
Symphony of Science is an online video series created by John D. Boswell, 
aka melodysheep, which aims to bring scientific knowledge and philosophy to 
the public, in a novel way, through the medium of music. Science and music 
are two passions of mine that I aim to combine, in a way that is intended 
to bring a meaningful message to listeners, while simultaneously providing 
an enjoyable musical experience. 

Video des Tages:
The Poetry of Reality is the fifth installment in the Symphony of Science 
music video series. It features 12 scientists and science enthusiasts, 
including Michael Shermer, Jacob Bronowski, Carl Sagan, Neil deGrasse 
Tyson, Richard Dawkins, Jill Tarter, Lawrence Krauss, Richard Feynman, 
Brian Greene, Stephen Hawking, Carolyn Porco, and PZ Myers, promoting 
science through words of wisdom. 

Ereignisse:
1607: Auf einer Insel im James River in der Kolonie Virginia gründen 104 
britische Siedler Jamestown, die erste dauerhafte Siedlung der Engländer in 
Amerika.
1692: In der Londoner Wochenzeitung Sammlung für den Fortschritt von 
Landwirtschaft und Handel erscheint der erste Wetterbericht, bei dem es 
sich jedoch nicht um eine Vorhersage sondern um einen Lagebericht handelt.
1796: Der englische Landarzt Edward Jenner verabreicht dem achtjährigen 
James Phipps die erste Schutzimpfung gegen Pocken aus einem von ihm 
entwickelten Serum aus Kuhpockenviren.
1878: Die Handelsmarke Vaseline wird für Robert Chesebrough registriert, 
der seit sechs Jahren das Patent auf die Herstellung der Salbe hält.
1939: Die Peruanerin Lina Medina wird in einem Krankenhaus in Lima von 
ihrem Sohn Gérardo entbunden. Die Mutter ist offiziell fünf Jahre, sieben 
Monate und 21 Tage alt und damit die jüngste Gebärende in der 
Medizingeschichte.
1940: Die niederländische Stadt Rotterdam wird im Zweiten Weltkrieg von der 
deutschen Luftwaffe bombardiert. Am Abend erklärt die niederländische Armee 
ihre Kapitulation im Mutterland.
1948: Israel unter Ministerpräsident David Ben Gurion erklärt seine 
Unabhängigkeit, womit das britische Völkerbundsmandat für Palästina endet. 
Der letzte britische Hochkommissar Alan Cunningham verlässt am gleichen Tag 
das Land. Noch in derselben Nacht erfolgt die Kriegserklärung der 
arabischen Nachbarn an den neu gegründeten Staat Israel.
1970: Während einer von seinem Anwalt Horst Mahler beantragten Ausführung 
gelingt Andreas Baader mit Hilfe von Ulrike Meinhof, Irene Goergens, Ingrid 
Schubert unter Einsatz von Schusswaffen die Flucht. Die Baader-Befreiung 
gilt als Geburtsstunde der Rote Armee Fraktion (RAF).
2005: Dem französischen Piloten Didier Delsalle gelingt mit einem 
Eurocopter AS 350 die erste Landung eines Hubschraubers auf dem Mount 
Everest für die Dauer von mindestens zwei Minuten. Nach der Aktion 
kritisiert weltweit eine Reihe von Personen den Rekordflug.

Geburtstage:
1808: Eduard Schott, deutscher Metallurge und Kunstgießer, Entdecker des 
Kristallisationsverfahrens
1884: Claude Dornier, deutscher Flugzeugkonstrukteur
1924: Coco Schumann, deutscher Jazzmusiker und Gitarrist
1928: Ernesto „Che“ Guevara, kubanischer Revolutionär und Guerillaführer, 
marxistischer Politiker und Autor
1952: David Byrne, britischer Musiker
1960: Anne Clark, britische Sängerin und Songwriterin
1961: Tim Roth, britischer Schauspieler
1965: Eoin Colfer, irischer Schriftsteller
1969: Cate Blanchett, australische Filmschauspielerin
1971: Sofia Coppola, US-amerikanische Filmregisseurin
1984: Mark Elliot Zuckerberg, US-amerikanischer Unternehmer, Gründer und 
Vorstandsvorsitzender von Facebook

Todestage:
649: Theodor I., Papst
964: Johannes XII., Papst
1912: August Strindberg, schwedischer Schriftsteller und Dramatiker
1987: Rita Hayworth, US-amerikanische Schauspielerin
1998: Frank Sinatra, US-amerikanischer Sänger, Schauspieler und Entertainer 
(Beiname The Voice)
2006: Günther Nenning, österreichischer Journalist, Autor, politischer 
Aktivist und Religionswissenschaftler﻿

comments.text:
To be fair, we came out of the dark ages 600 years ago, the industrial 
revolution started 200 years ago, plastic (one of the most commonly used 
materials nowadays) was invented 100 years ago, and the internet is around 
about 20 years old.

When you think about it that way, the fact that we've gotten to this stage 
is pretty damn impressive. Science isn't new, but the concept of it has 
always been controversial. At least we don't get sentenced to death for 
practicing it anymore.
